thread.title: Rangers, Royals wrap up key wins
thread.title_full: Rangers, Royals wrap up key wins

title: Rangers, Royals wrap up key wins
text:
Rangers, Royals wrap up key wins By Mike Tupa mtupa@examiner-enterprise.com 
Are the Kansas City Royals poised to push past the Toronto Blue Jays for the top seed in the American League? 
On Thursday, they offered a partial “yes” to that question with a 6-4 victory against the Chicago White Sox. 
Kansas City and Toronto are now tied for the No. 1 spot — and postseason homefield advantage through the league playoffs — heading into the final weekend. 
Mike Moustakas’ RBI ground-rule double in the top of the first pushed Kansas City to a 1-0 lead. The Royals would stay in front the rest of the way. 
In the top of the third, Kansas City cruised to a 4-0 lead, thanks to another run scoring hit by Moustakas, and a two-run single by Jonny Gomes. 
The White Sox clawed back to within two runs, 4-2, in the bottom of the third, including a run-scoring hit by Tracye Thompson. 
But, Kansas City staged a two-run uprising in the top of the fifth — highlighted by Gomes’ sacrifice fly — to put the game out of reach on this particular day. 
Kris Medlen (6-2) started on the mound for Kansas City and captured the win. He allowed four hits and two runs (one earned) through six innings. Ryan Madson nailed down his third save. 
White Sox starter John Danks (7-15) suffered the loss after giving up 11 hits and six runs in five innings. 
Texas 5, L.A. Angels 3 
There’s no hope remaining for the Los Angeles Angels for a division title. 
The Angels fell to the Texas Rangers, 5-3, in a slobberknocker in Arlington, Texas. 
The victory reduced the Texas Rangers’ magic number to one to win the A.L. West Division Title. 
The Angels, meanwhile, fell to four games behind the Rangers with only three games remaining. 
That means the best the Angels can do is to try to pull past the Houston Astros for the final wildcard playoff spot. 
Texas — an improbable division winner, should it pull out the title — relied on several different offensive producers to turn back the Angels. 
In the bottom of the fifth, Delino DeShields delivered a RBI double — which scored Elvis Andrus — and Adrian Beltre doubled home Robinson Chirinos, DeShields and Shin-soo Choo to propel the Rangers into the lead, 4-1. 
Two innings later, Josh Hamilton lifted a sacrifice fly to plate Beltre. 
Albert Pujols cranked a solo homer in the sixth inning for what would be the Angels’ biggest offensive highlight. 
Pujols banged his 39 th homer, his most in a season since 42 in 2010, with the St. Louis Cardinals. But, barring an explosive final weekend, he’s on target to finish with fewer than 100 RBIs — he now has 92 — for just third time in his 15-year Major League career. 
Derek Holland (4-3) collected the pitching victory as the Rangers’ starter; Andrew Heaney (6-4) suffered the mound defeat. Rules for posting comments
